ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic adult-onset cerebellar ataxia presenting with unsteady gait and nystagmus. Age of onset typically in 30s-40s, matching patient's age.
Common SCA subtype with cerebellar ataxia and nystagmus. Typically presents in 30s-40s with progressive gait ataxia.
Common demyelinating disease presenting in young adults with cerebellar signs including ataxia and nystagmus. Age and symptoms fit well.
Most common hereditary ataxia, though typically presents earlier. Late-onset forms can present in 30s with gait ataxia and nystagmus.
Autosomal dominant ataxia with typical onset in 30s-40s. Presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia and eye movement abnormalities.
Characterized by episodic ataxia and interictal nystagmus. Can present in adulthood with gait difficulties between episodes.

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Cerebellar ataxia, mental retardation, and dysequilibrium syndrome 1
ranked_diseases.explanation: Congenital ataxia syndrome with nystagmus and gait abnormalities, though typically presents from birth. Milder forms possible.
Machado-Joseph disease. Common SCA with typical onset in 30s-40s, presenting with ataxia and eye movement abnormalities.
